title: MLabs - Spec DSL for dApp Security
description: Cardano was designed to support secure smart contracts. Yet, testing, auditing, and even designing Cardano dApps involve serious challenges.

f6_assessments.q0:
This addresses the challenge in a little bit of an abstract way. The challenge is to build dApps for official registries at the national level. 

These dApps need to be secure. Many parts of testing and writing dApps can share code. So it follows that this project supports the challenge. 

A concern with making this leap of logic is that there is no guarantee that this work will be accessible to the governments that need it. Some of the poorest countries could make the best use of nation building dApps. If this DSL were too expensive for those countries to use, then this grant would not be well spent. 

The proposal could benefit from some mechanism, or guarantee that the DSL be available for governments of developing nations.

f6_assessments.q0:
I strongly agree that this proposal will bring a unique value and hence impact on the Cardano open source developer ecosystem. The problem statement is clear, as many developers are self taught programmers and do not necessarily hold a formal mathematics background. The summarized solution to the problem in a nutshell will provide a DSL (domain specific language), which is in plain terms a simpler version of providing a bunch of logical statements as close as possible to natural language such as English.

As a senior developer myself I can see the importance of such a proposal. Blockchain is immutable and Cardano will soon have tens of thousands of dapps running on it. Therefore, it is very important that those dapps are as robust as possible before they go live. 

The solution proposed by this project will essentially allow developers to test their smart contracts against a predefined set of rules (based on their scripts business logic) in a DSL and formally have a testing process prior to mainnet deployment. 

Additionally, it would be also possible to translate these rules then into the code itself, something on the lines of test driven OR feature driven development (a practice widely known in Software Engineering). This will allow developers to have a lot more confidence with their plutus scripts and find issues before they go live. 

Great proposal and Good luck to the team.

The developers from this company have already been part of many successful projects on Cardano such as SundaeSwap, Liquid, Ardana, to name a few of them. The company is also an official IOG (company behind Cardano) plutus partner and holds the right experience needed to build such a DSL spec.The profile links for main developers and delivery manager behind this proposal are given and one can see that they hold the expertise to implement this proposal successfully.

As a senior developer myself I can see that the budget asked for is devoted entirely to Engineering hours, which in my opinion is the entirety of efforts needed for its successful implementation. The total time is broken very well into individual tasks/milestones, which showcases that the team has very well thought through the engineering efforts that are needed to achieve this proposal. However, it would have been great if hours were also represented in terms of how many months/weeks it will take to finish this. As many voters/community members are more used to looking at weekly/monthly timeframes. 

Additionally, one of the concerns I have is how accurate the DSL would be because a lot of projects will rely on its implementation, however, this is already mentioned in the risks and challenges section. Nevertheless, I can see a lot of improvements and a lot more community (maybe also IOG, as they have already given us Marlowe) support dropping in to improve the development of this DSL.

Very nice proposal and looking forward to its implementation, with or without funding. Good luck.

f6_assessments.q0:
As testing, auditing, and designing Cardano dApps is challenging, the team proposes a domain specification language (DSL) for describing dApp behavior and generating tests to validate an implementation against its design.
So the proposal addresses the challenge of providing an open source tool for the developement ecosystem.
The benefits in using the new DSL are the following:

• cut costs by reducing auditing, developing, designing architecture, cutting testing time

• build dApps that interoperate securely with others.

• configure the value types their smart contracts can handle and test assertions 

• employ automated or human-directed proofs of application function

• define the types of transactions a system can handle

• automate code generation

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a proposal that will enable developers to make sure their Dapps and smart contracts never fall in an incorrect state. To put it clearly, when you're creating a smart contract to send tokens, you never want to send the wrong token. This proposal would give you the tool you need to assert a constant valid state of the application and/or smart contract. It's an amazing idea and very difficult to pull of, but by the looks of it, there will be steady progress if this proposal is voted in. The project falls in perfectly in the bounds of the challenge, enabling future cardano developers to write consistent and secure Dapps.
The value added to the Cardano ecosystem would be immence, especially for developers such as myself. Much of the exploits happening on other chains are due to smart 
contracts falling into an invalid state the developer didn't expect and such tools can help with that as well. I like the goals of the proposal as they strive to help developers grow the skills necessary to make Cardano even more economically competitive.
I don't see any problem for the proposal to scale for one main reason. Usually tools such as these can be run offline, but it would have been nice for this detail to be mentioned in the proposal. The whole idea of a DSL to test and assert states and properties of the smart contract is not by any means new, but I can't stress enough how necessary the actual implementation is so kudos to the guys developing this. This proposal adds a big chunk missing from the currently available tooling.
As a developer I don't have any concerns about this proposal as it seems the authors of the proposal have covered all the bases. The only thing for me to do is vote for them and wish them good luck. I'll definately be following along with their progress.
f6_assessments.q1:
There are more than enoug evidence provided in the form of skills descriptions, github repositories and profiles of the team members. I was able to find information about each of them and was more than happy with what I found, excluding what was already described in the proposal. I have absolutely no doubt that the listed members would be able to finish the job. More than that the proposers have team ready instead of individuals, which is a small but importand difference when you need to the work.
The budget is broken down into hourly rate for each stage of the proposal including the actual development and research before that. The 72000 they request devided by 900 hours to complete the project brings the hourly rate to 80 $/hour which is fair for a task with such difficulty. You might not appreciate what they're trying to do, but beleve me, it's complicated and I'm really happy they have so many mathematically profiled people on the team.
I wouldn't presume to know if the timetable is relevant or not, because I haven't done such work before and I couldn't estimate properly, but I would defer to their judgement as proffessionals. The one thing I can talk about though is the segregation of tasks to be done till the project is completed, and I really like they have included time for proper research and categorization of the problems they're going to tackle. Furthermore they are aware of the fact, corner cases will pop up, but they keep their eyes on the prize and will strive to cover the general purpose cases before diving to the side. This requires some level of discipline and is comendible.
The technical aspects are more then well explained and some part of the proposal is an actual tutorial on how things work and a brief history of the space to give the reader context for the incomming problem. The team has considered their biggest challenge and I really think they're spot on with it, because the general case is not perfect but will help a lot of developers learn and grow while keeping mistakes minimum.
The project is in sync with the ecosystem and to be hones I've been wating for such a tool for some time now, so if it's voted in, I'm deffinately using it to learn how to write better smart contracts and Dapps. Good job!
f6_assessments.q2:
So long as the project is in the Open source challenge category and there's a public GitHub repository, I see no problems with tracability and anyone interested in the project will be able to follow along with the implementation.
The metrics and KPIs seem reasonable. Benchmarking is really necessary for tooling such as this, because once developers start relying on you, you need to provide them with the stable ground on which to stand on. In this sense benchmarking performance and common sense scenarios is a really important metric. A metric that I haven't seen before is the documentation, but it really seems like a good one, because (speaking from experience) you can never have too much documentation. The more people ask about how the tooling works, the more documentation should appear in the perfect world. 
As I already mentioned I really like the roadmap and the specific milestones that are put in. It's clear that a lot of thought was put into them. There's a clear and understandable problem, prefixed with a short history to provide context. The solution description of the problem is really well expressed as well. The only thing I would suggest is for the proposers to limit the terminology unless it's necessary. Overall a great proposal! 5/5 on all fronts.
